data.title: Is the fuel enough?
data.statement:
You are traveling to a friend's house, but you cannot fill up the tank completely to be sure you will arrive. That's why you are calculating based on your car's fuel consumption whether it is possible.

If it is possible (to reach the destination), the message {{Perfect.}} should be displayed.
If it will just be enough (to reach the destination), the message {{50/50. On your own risk.}} should be displayed.
If there is fuel in the tank but it won't be enough (to reach the destination), the message {{There isn't enough fuel.}} should be displayed.
If there is no fuel in the tank, the message {{There is no fuel in the tank.}} should be displayed.

testCases.title: There is no fuel in the tank.
testCases.testOut: There is no fuel in the tank.

testCases.title: Validator 4
testCases.testOut: There is no fuel in the tank.

<<Line 1:>>  An integer [[fuel]] representing the fuel in the car
<<Line 2:>>  A float variable [[AverageFuelConsumption]] representing the fuel consumption per 100 kilometers
<<Line 3:>>  An integer [[km]] representing how many kilometers is it to your friend's house
data.outputDescription: <<Line 1>>: A string that is one of the four possible outcome messages.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

You are traveling to a friend's house, but you cannot fill up the tank completely to be sure you will arrive. That's why you are calculating based on your car's fuel consumption whether it is possible.

If it is possible (to reach the destination), the message Perfect. should be displayed.
If it will just be enough (to reach the destination), the message 50/50. On your own risk. should be displayed.
If there is fuel in the tank but it won't be enough (to reach the destination), the message There isn't enough fuel. should be displayed.
If there is no fuel in the tank, the message There is no fuel in the tank. should be displayed.
Input
Line 1: An integer fuel representing the fuel in the car
Line 2: A float variable AverageFuelConsumption representing the fuel consumption per 100 kilometers
Line 3: An integer km representing how many kilometers is it to your friend's house
Output
Line 1: A string that is one of the four possible outcome messages.
Constraints
0 ≤ fuel ≤ 60
0.0 < AverageFuelConsumption ≤ 9.0
0 < km ≤ 1000
Example
Input
30
5.6
530
Output
Perfect.
